On Thursday 05 May 2005 21:34, Igor Ranitovic wrote:
> -1.
>
> I am not und=
er impression that the src tree is (yet) polluted with unit
> tests. Though=
, it would be great to be in that position.  At this point, I
> think that =
we should keep them as is (in your face) as a constant reminder
> that unit=
 tests should/must be written.
>
> i.

It's true. Heritrix still does not h=
ave all classes tested. However, we 
already have more than 60 unit tests (=
and more than 300 application classes). 
That's about 20% coverage already!=
 But I think that if you keep the test case 
classes inside src/main, their=
 number won't increase over the next few month  
(it should!) -- they simpl=
y appear as "some additional classes", and nobody 
really would care/dare t=
o add a bunch of new ones if he is not forced to (due 
to bugs etc.) If I w=
ould now take this job and start writing basic test cases 
for each class, =
the problem would arise immediately (=3D the src/main tree 
would be remark=
ably polluted after one CVS commit).

So yes: for now, having only a few te=
sts, it is not a big issue. But if we 
want to have all classes tested, we =
should provide the necessary 
infrastructure as soon as possible, in order =
to boost test case creation.

Also, remember, test cases currently show up =
in the API javadocs, where they 
shouldn't be. For a novice, this makes get=
ting an overview unnecessarily 
complicated.

In my projects, I create diff=
erent source trees from the beginning, even if 
not every class is tested b=
eforehands. For me, having them separated is a 
necessity. It makes things =
much easier, *especially*  reminding me that unit 
tests must be written.

=
So, from my point of view, a strong +1.
